Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I experienced a fraudulent ACH transfer of {$4800.00} from my XXXX XXXX account to an unauthorized XXXX account. The scammer cleverly spoofed XXXX XXXX 's customer service number, making it appear legitimate. While I didn't reveal any personal information, the scammer initiated the transfer regardless. 

Disturbingly, XXXX XXXX acknowledged they are aware of this spoofing tactic and that scammers replicate their scam alert process. Furthermore, they claim all customer information is already compromised on the dark web. 

My Concerns : Security Gaps : Why hasn't XXXX XXXX changed their customer service number or implemented stronger authentication methods if they know it's being spoofed? 
Customer Awareness : Why haven't they proactively informed customers about this vulnerability? 
Delayed Resolution : XXXX XXXX requires an investigation before crediting my stolen funds. This delay is unacceptable, and the stolen amount should be immediately reimbursed. 
This incident highlights a concerning lack of customer protection. XXXX XXXX seems aware of the scam methods yet fails to take adequate preventative measures. 

I urge XXXX XXXX to : Improve security protocols to prevent further spoofing. 
Inform customers about these scams and how to identify them. 
Expedite the return of stolen funds.

Issue: Problem with a lender or other company charging your account
Consumer complaint narrative: After meeting with a company in XX/XX/2023 my husband and I decided to liquidate our timeshare. This agency represented themselves as a time share exit team. They sent out paperwork to gather data about our purchase and then they sent me a numerical figure that they stated would be the amount needed to liquidate our timeshare. They shared information about closing cost, and what would be needed to transfer the deed. On XX/XX/2023 a transaction in the amount of {$11000.00} was made. It was supposed to be for the liquidation of a timeshare/payoff. The representative from XXXX XXXX XXXX called after saying they didn't receive the cashiers check ( I sent it 30 days before noting the timeshare exit payoff in the notes section ). After I canceled the check at the bank, they asked if we could just debit the money as it would be quicker and we could move along the process to get out of the timeshare. I gave him the debit information and later that evening he sent a XXXX for me to initial electronically for the debit ( only one page ). Later on, when he sent me the finalized XXXX agreement, there were additional pages that showed a contract for purchasing into a travel program with XXXX in that exact amount. I didn't agree to that, but there were my digital initials on the form which I knew I never signed. I reached out to the representative immediately and said that's not what I agreed to. In his text message he agreed that this was his understanding and that he would have someone from the company to reach out to me. That never happened and I continued to try and contact someone. When I called XXXX, they said it was through a third party so they couldn't do anything. XXXX XXXX would not respond via phone or email. When I tried to email XXXX, they blocked me. I filed a complaint through the XXXX and they continued to say I signed the form to purchase from XXXX ... when in fact I did not. They continue to reference the contract language to deflect any responsibility, but all they had to do was refund my money. I have never used their service, and I even declined free items when offered stating I just wanted to liquidate my timeshare. When I tried to retrieve the history from the XXXX, it was blank forms. I feel this is a scam being perpetuated by these entities and each one is blaming the other. I only gave permission to payoff my timeshare ( which didn't happen ), not purchase into another company.
Company public response: None

Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/2023, I applied for an extension of My credit at State Employees credit Union. I was denied for credit history and basically I didnt make enough. I am devastated. After speaking with loan officer, I asked was she the underwriter, she told me No. After She spoke with her supervisor supposedly. She said it was my credit history and recent chargeoffs. I told her someone was working on my credit because someone fraudulently used my social security number. I then asked to speak with the underwriter. She replied I am the Underwriter. I then mentioned 12 Cfr 1002.4. I felt discriminated against. I also mentioned Title 15 subsection 1611 faults and misleading denial of credit. I asked for all the factors that played a role in this consumer transaction. She than said she didnt know what I was talking about. She havent heard those codes before. I told her if she was an underwriter Im sure someone mentioned them one time or another. I asked for a printout of the factors the played a role and denying me access to an extension of my credit. She said it would be mailed to me. I told her I was denied so it should be on the screen. I asked to speak with a manager who may know these codes. She then brought the bank manager in and she said we are sorry your denial is because of charge off and credit History. At this point I was heartbroken. I told her if its charged off they were paid so it shouldnt be on my credit and gave her my spill about fraudulent activity on my social security number. The manager told me something will be mailed to me. After leaving the bank, I thought I left my phone and four employees were huddling talking about this matter. Later that day I received a call that I can pick up paperwork Tuesday morning and She spoke to Vp of company and I was still denied. It was a Friday XXXX XXXX and it was a XXXX Monday.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I attempted approximately XXXX times to deposit my initial paycheck via NFCU mobile app. Although the image was indeed clear, I constantly received the error message that the check could not be deposited. I wrote the mobile deposit disclaimer below my signature as instructed. Knowing that Christmas was approaching, I drove a long distance to the nearest NFCU atm to deposit the check. The ATM would not accept the check. I tried again at the next ATM, the same outcome. This experience is unfair as I am aware of several other members who have been able to utilize the ATM and mobile deposit features for amounts way larger. Additionally, the mobile deposit feature has been heavily advertised by the credit union. My check not being accepted is disparate impact and treatment. The payroll check was {$3100.00}. I also dont have any history of scams or depositing bad checks. 

The next day I called in late for work to walk my check in the branch around XXXX. The teller advised my funds would not be available until XX/XX/XXXX, Tuesday, the day after Christmas. She explained the Thursday would not count as a business day although I made the deposit before Thursday nights processing time. 

Friday morning I woke up to an email from NFCU stating my funds would be delayed an additional XXXX business days, as they had confidential information indicating the check may not be paid giving the them reasonable cause to believe the check would be uncollectible. In response, I provided my employers payroll email and phone number and corporate address for verification. I work for XXXXXXXX XXXX an in house lender for one of the largest developers on the XXXX XXXX. My new employers payroll account is with XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. I also explained that I am aware of several members who have never been subject to extended delayed times when making deposits. This too, is a UDAAP violation and example of disparate treatment. 

In typical corporate greedy fashion, the banks only response was to send me a list of their deposit policies. 

Screenshots corroborating my response are attached.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Back in 2023, my husband and I have decided that we want to take the necessary steps of buying a house and pulled our credit reports to see make sure it was in good standings. I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding the actions of State Employees Credit Union ( SECU ) in relation to my account ( XXXX ) and their failure to provide necessary documentation, as well as their wrongful reporting practices, which have had severe consequences on my financial stability and well-being. 

According to Section 15 USC 1681 ( g ) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), consumers have the right to request and receive a copy of any XXXX forms for XXXX debts. Despite repeated requests to SECU, I have not received the required XXXX forms for the charge off ( XXXX ) associated with my account ( XXXX ). This failure to provide essential documentation has left me in a precarious financial situation, impacting my ability to provide for my family and jeopardizing our well-being. 

Furthermore, under Section 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( XXXX ) of the FCRA, creditors are obligated to provide accurate information to credit reporting agencies. However, SECU has wrongfully reported these charge off accounts, which have had a detrimental effect on my XXXX XXXX and financial standing. This inaccurate reporting has exacerbated the challenges I face in maintaining my financial stability and has hindered my ability to access necessary credit and resources. 

Additionally, I have submitted disputes regarding these fraudulent accounts to SECU. However, despite my efforts to rectify the situation, SECU has continued to report these disputed accounts, further damaging my XXXX XXXX and exacerbating my financial hardships. According to FCRA regulations, reporting on disputed accounts should be suspended until the dispute is resolved, yet SECU has disregarded this requirement, causing significant harm to my financial well-being.

Therefore, I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate these violations of the FCRA by SECU and take appropriate action to ensure that my rights as a consumer are upheld. Specifically, I request that SECU be compelled to provide the necessary XXXX forms for the charge off ( XXXX ) in question and that the wrongfully reported accounts be removed from my credit report immediately. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I trust that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will take swift and decisive action to address these violations and protect consumers like myself from unjust and harmful practices by financial institutions.

Consumer complaint narrative:
After reviewing mortgage documents, it seems that I was misled in what I was actually signing. It seems that a trust agreement was signed instead of a contact for a " mortgage loan ''. In light of this I claimed the property to be a part of my estate and sent a Qualified Written Request under RESPA that was served to NCSECU on XX/XX/year> asking for specific accounting details of the alleged " loan ''. I will attached all documents that were sent to NCSECU. I also notified the IRS of this transaction, ( which I was unaware I needed to at the time ) by filing a 1099-OID and a 1099-A for acquisition of the property. The IRS accepted and sent copies of these forms to NCSECU. I know that they received them as they in return sent that copy B for both forms back to me. 

On XX/XX/year> I received a response stating that NCSECU had received my documents ( QWR and estate claim ) dated XX/XX/year>, but to please be advised that they are " unable to accept my documents ''. 
As the CFPB and NCSECU is aware, a servicer is required to respond to a QWR request within 30 days - or request an appropriate additional time for the request to be answered. Per their response- they have no intention of providing the information, although they have acknowledged they received the Qualified Written Request under RESPA. This is serious cause for concern. If a " loan '' was provided to me in the manner I was told it was, why would there be any hesitation to provide the accounting details of the loan.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a complaint against Caine & Weiner regarding their violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). The collection agency in question has added a debt to my credit history without any agreement or written authorization from me. 


Despite my request that they return the alleged debt to the original creditor, the collection agency has continued to pursue collection activities against me, which I believe is a violation of my rights under the FDCPA. I have also requested debt validation, as is my right under the FDCPA, but the agency has not provided me with any proof that I owe this debt. 
I believe that this collection agency has violated several provisions of the FDCPA, including but not limited to : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 2 ) ( A ) - falsely representing the character, amount, or legal status of the debt 2. 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 5 ) - threatening to take any action that can not legally be taken or that is not intended to be taken 3. 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 10 ) - using false representations or deceptive means to collect or attempt to collect any debt 4. 15 U.S.C. 1692f ( 1 ) - using unfair or unconscionable means to collect or attempt to collect any debt I am requesting that the CFPB investigate this collection agency for their violations of the FDCPA and take appropriate action to ensure that they cease all collection activities related to this debt and that they correct any negative reporting on my credit history.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Against Navy Federal for Denial of Extension Request on Auto Loans Date : XX/XX/year> I am writing to file a formal complaint against Navy Federal regarding the denial of my extension request for two auto loans that I hold with the institution. Despite multiple attempts to communicate my situation to Navy Federal, I have been met with a lack of understanding and cooperation, leading to undue financial hardship on my part. 

I have diligently explained to Navy Federal that I was on XXXX XXXXXXXX leave from work and only recently returned to work on XX/XX/XXXX. In light of my financial circumstances, I reached out to Navy Federal 's personal finance team to request an extension for my two auto loans. Initially, in XXXX, I was informed that both loans would qualify for a two-month extension after making my payments. However, when I followed up on this agreement, it was arbitrarily downgraded to a one-month extension without my consent. 

This unilateral decision by XXXX XXXX felt like a bait-and-switch tactic, leaving me feeling deceived and manipulated. I made it clear that the two-month extension was crucial for me to catch up on my auto loan payments, especially given that I was awaiting payments from my long-term leave company, XXXX, which were pending then and remain pending now.

Despite my genuine efforts to negotiate a reasonable solution that aligned with my financial constraints, Navy Federal 's representative insisted that I either accept the one-month extension or receive no extension at all. Feeling pressured and cornered into an agreement that I knew I could not uphold, I reluctantly agreed to the one-month extension, knowing that it would not provide me with adequate time to receive my long-term benefits and catch up on my bills.

As a responsible individual committed to meeting my financial obligations, the treatment I have received from Navy Federal has been distressing and burdensome. This denial of a fair and reasonable extension has significantly impacted my ability to prevent homelessness and provide for my family 's basic needs.

I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate this matter thoroughly and hold Navy Federal accountable for their unfair and deceptive practices. I seek a resolution that is just and equitable, considering the financial hardship and emotional distress that I have endured due to Navy Federal 's actions.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Credit monitoring or identity theft protection services
Consumer complaint narrative:
We received your complaint. Thank you. 
We will review your complaint. Depending on what we find, we will typically : Send your complaint to the company for a response ; or Send your complaint to another state or federal agency, or help you get in touch with your state or local consumer protection office ; or Let you know if we need more information to continue our work. 
YOUR COMPLAINT XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 16 CFR 313.12, 16 CFR 433.1, 16 CFR 433.2 , 16 CFR 433.3 ( Stop reporting my utilization score on any and all accounts reporting on my credit score ) Person. An individual, corporation, or any other business organization. ( b ) Consumer. A natural person who seeks or acquires goods or services for personal, family, or household use. ( c ) Creditor. A person who, in the ordinary course of business, lends purchase money or finances the sale of goods or services to consumers on a deferred payment basis ; Provided, such person is not acting, for the purposes of a particular transaction, in the capacity of a credit card issuer. ( d ) Purchase money loan. A cash advance which is received by a consumer in return for a Finance Charge within the meaning of the Truth in Lending Act and Regulation Z, which is applied, in whole or substantial part, to a purchase of goods or services from a seller who ( 1 ) refers consumers to the creditor or ( 2 ) is affiliated with the creditor by common control, contract, or business arrangement. ( e ) Financing a sale. Extending credit to a consumer in connection with a Credit Sale within the meaning of the Truth in Lending Act and Regulation Z. ( f ) Contract. Any oral or written agreement, formal or informal, between a creditor and a seller, which contemplates or provides for cooperative or concerted activity in connection with the sale of goods or services to consumers or the financing thereof. ( g ) Business arrangement. Any understanding, procedure, course of dealing, or arrangement, formal or informal, between a creditor and a seller, in connection with the sale of goods or services to consumers or the financing thereof. ( h ) Credit card issuer. A person who extends to cardholders the right to use a credit card in connection with purchases of goods or services. ( i ) Consumer credit contract. Any instrument which evidences or embodies a debt arising from a Purchase Money Loan transaction or a financed sale as defined in paragraphs ( d ) and ( e ) of this section. ( j ) Seller. A person who, in the ordinary course of business, sells or leases goods or services to consumers. 433.2 Preservation of consumers ' claims and defenses, unfair or deceptive acts or practices. In connection with any sale or lease of goods or services to consumers, in or affecting commerce as commerce is defined in the Federal Trade Commission Act, it is an unfair or deceptive act or practice within the meaning of section 5 of that Act for a seller, directly or indirectly, to : ( a ) Take or receive a consumer credit contract which fails to contain the following provision in at least ten point, bold face, type : NOTICE ANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED PURSUANT HERETO OR WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER. or, ( b ) Accept, as full or partial payment for such sale or lease, the proceeds of any purchase money loan ( as purchase money loan is defined herein ), unless any consumer credit contract made in connection with such purchase money loan contains the following provision in at least ten point, bold face, type : NOTICE ANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER. 433.3 Exemption of sellers taking or receiving open end consumer credit contracts before November 1, 1977 from requirements of 433.2 ( a ). ( a ) Any seller who has taken or received an open end consumer credit contract before November 1, 1977, shall be exempt from the requirements of 16 CFR part 433 with respect to such contract provided the contract does not cut off consumers ' claims and defenses. ( b ) Definitions. The following definitions apply to this exemption : ( 1 ) All pertinent definitions contained in 16 CFR 433.1. ( 2 ) Open end consumer credit contract : a consumer credit contract pursuant to which open end credit is extended. ( 3 ) Open end credit : consumer credit extended on an account pursuant to a plan under which a creditor may permit an applicant to make purchases or make loans, from time to time, directly from the creditor or indirectly by use of a credit card, check, or other device, as the plan may provide. The term does not include negotiated advances under an open-end real estate mortgage or a letter of credit. ( 4 ) Contract which does not cut off consumers ' claims and defenses : A consumer credit contract which does not constitute or contain a negotiable instrument, or contain any waiver, limitation, term, or condition which has the effect of limiting a consumer 's right to assert against any holder of the contract all legally sufficient claims and defenses which the consumer could assert against the seller of goods or services purchased pursuant to the contract. 313.12 Limits on sharing account number information for marketing purposes. ( a ) General prohibition on disclosure of account numbers. You must not, directly or through an affiliate, disclose, other than to a consumer reporting agency, an account number or similar form of access number or access code for a consumer 's credit card account, deposit account, or transaction account to any nonaffiliated third party for use in telemarketing, direct mail marketing, or other marketing through electronic mail to the consumer. ( b ) Exceptions. Paragraph ( a ) of this section does not apply if you disclose an account number or similar form of access number or access code : ( 1 ) To your agent or service provider solely in order to perform marketing for your own products or services, as long as the agent or service provider is not authorized to directly initiate charges to the account; or ( 2 ) To a participant in a private label credit card program or an affinity or similar program where the participants in the program are identified to the customer when the customer enters into the program. ( c ) Examples ( 1 ) Account number. An account number, or similar form of access number or access code, does not include a number or code in an encrypted form, as long as you do not provide the recipient with a means to decode the number or code. ( 2 ) Transaction account. A transaction account is an account other than a deposit account or a credit card account. A transaction account does not include an account to which third parties can not initiate charges.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Card was charged for something you did not purchase with the card
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been an account holder for over a decade. I have always paid my bill as agreed, which is due monthly on the XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, I went to pay my bill online as I do every month. I noticed that instead of the ~ $ XXXX bill I was planning to pay towards, the bill was over $ XXXX, and immediately began to research the charges on the account. I observed that on XX/XX/XXXX, a {$2.00} charge was made at a local XXXX, and on XX/XX/XXXX a {$7200.00} cash advance was made at a branch. I navigated to the websites fraud claim reporting system and immediately reported the fraudulent activity, since neither of the charges were authorized by me. The bank removed the charges and began their investigation. In the interim, I discovered that the charges were made on the card that belongs to my authorized user, who is my nephew. Since my authorized user was out of town at the time of the charges due to being in a training camp, after speaking with him, and confirming he had never used nor received the card, I questioned my brother, who has the same name as my authorized user. My brother straightway indicated that he had gone into both the XXXX and the branch and had in fact made the charges on what he believed to be HIS card. He indicated that he had previously applied for a card with the same institution and was under the impression that the card he was using was his. He further stated that he went into the branch with his own ID and was never questioned about his identity. Until I mentioned the situation with my card and my authorized user, he still was under the impression that he was in possession of his own card. The bank subsequently reversed the credit and put both charges plus interest back on my card. 

I informed the bank that they did not verify the party at the branch, because had they done so, they would have realized that although the party has the same first and last name, their date of birth is not the same. I told the XXXX on XXXX of many phone calls made to the institution, that they made a mistake and gave a huge cash advance to a non-authorized party against my account. They refused to own up to their mistake, and instead accused myself and my authorized user of sending the wrong party into the branch to make a cash advance. They are now not only charging me for their mistaken {$7200.00} cash advance, but also the interest involved, which is very expensive. I have been going back and forth with the institution for several months, and they refuse to acknowledge their error. Both parties have the same first and last name, but my authorized user is solely my nephew and not my brother. Their date of birth is very similar. The one being XX/XX/XXXX ( which is my authorized users dob ) and the other being XX/XX/XXXX ( which is my brothers XXXX ). They did not follow sound " know your customer '' procedures, and as a result, they put my account, and my finances in jeopardy, and are creating a severe hardship for me in keeping up with the much higher payments associated with these unauthorized charges. The bank needs to be held accountable for their error and not charge me, a long-standing customer with their mistake. They are now reporting this higher balance to the bureaus after being made aware of their mistake. They refuse to acknowledge, and now with the higher balance on this credit card, my score has dropped XXXX points. This is a violation of my rights as a consumer, and a violation of accurate reporting. Please help me with this egregious treatment. Because it is the bank 's negligence in verifying the customer that entered the bank, which has caused me this hassle and expense.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: A charge off account is showing on my report & the creditor told me that I can not get a copy of the 1099-C document because they did not officially charge off the debt and they didn't take a write off which is a violation because it says on my credit report that it is charged off which equates to false reporting & not reporting 100 % accurately. FCRA violations refers to a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which is a federal law that regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer credit information. Federal law requires that consumer reporting agencies follow reasonable procedures to ensure 100 % accuracy of the information contained in their credit reports. If a consumer suffers damages as a result of a FCRA violation they may be entitled to bring a private lawsuit against the CRA and recover actual damages, statutory damages, and attorney 's fees. These accounts listed on my letter are not 100 % correct and I demand them to be investigated completely.
Company public response: None

Which is unacceptable. 

******************************************************************************* Can a debt collector take my federal benefits, like Social Security or VA payments? 

Before a debt collector can take Social Security or VA benefits, they must sue you and win a judgment against you for the amount you owe. Then, the debt collector must get a court order that tells your bank or credit union to turn over money from your account or prepaid card. This is called garnishment. 

The key to making sure your federal benefits are legally protected from being frozen or garnished is to use direct deposit to put the money into your account or prepaid card. You can sign up anytime to have federal benefits direct deposited to your bank account or loaded onto a prepaid card. 

As long as I am using direct deposit, which federal benefits are protected? 
Money you receive and direct deposit to your account or card from the following government programs is protected : Social Security benefits Supplemental Security Income ( SSI ) benefits Veterans benefits Civil service and federal retirement and XXXX benefits Servicemember pay Military annuities and survivor benefits Federal student aid Railroad retirement benefits Financial assistance from the Federal Emergency Management Agency ( FEMA ) ********************************************* XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I am requesting all correspondences be submitted to CFPB ONLY Do not call or Write. I want the correspondence accessible to the regulators and in writing electronically stamps. 

Copies Sent to / via : Navy Federal Credit Union Consumer Financial Protection Bureau All Correspondences Can be sent to : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: I fell ill in late XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX and was out of work with no pay for XXXX weeks. I contacted XXXX Credit Card company late XXXX for financial assistance as I could not get my feet back on the ground once returning to work. I originally was told I qualified for credit protection, that I have been paying for the entire time I had this card. I did exactly what they told me to do supplied with a note from my doctor. I did not hear back for over 30 days ( the time told it may take to process ). When I reached back out I was told by a supervisor I was declined from the program as it turns out I did not meet the requirements for credit protection like they originally thought. Because I was not out of work for XXXX days or more, it was only XXXX days, they declined the protection. Keeping in mind I only signed up for credit protection as my chronic documented medical illness was supposed to be covered by their protection provided I have doctors notes of being under a doctor 's care for a significant amount of time ( as it is in all my other credit cards too, suffering from illness for XXXX years now so I am always sure to check this ). The supervisor was extremely rude saying if I was sick for longer I would qualify but I was about XXXX week short of that. He said I could do the re-age program and sent me over to sign up for that. Lovely woman got me all set up, she told me if I sign up to split my delinquent amount up into XXXX autopay monthly payments my account would be current so long as I made all XXXX payments. I have made XXXX of the XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ) and got a notice of my account still being past due ( today XX/XX/XXXX ). I contacted the company to which I was told the re-age program does NOT bring accounts current until AFTER the payments are made, thus my credit will be hit when the XXXX days ( month XXXX ) of the program ends. I would never have signed up for this program if it was going to affect my credit, I would have worked to try to find other arrangements to make my account current. Now, we are months into trying to get assistance to no avail all while my credit is taking massive hits. The only thing I was told repeatedly today when asking how this re-age program will affect my credit and what options I have is a repeated response " we report fairly and accurately, I recommend calling in for further assistance. '' At this point, this response seems extremely sketchy that they offered me this program but will not speak to how it affects my credit. In doing some research on my own I'm seeing re-age programs are illegal? I am at a loss and don't even trust this company so looking for assistance from anyone who can tell me what is going on, what is best for me, and how this credit card has impacted my credit score.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Navy Federal is in violation of 15 USC 6802.

15 U.S. Code 6802 - Obligations with respect to disclosures of personal information ( a ) Notice requirements Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, a financial institution may not, directly or through any affiliate, disclose to a nonaffiliated third party any nonpublic personal information, unless such financial institution provides or has provided to the consumer a notice that complies with section 6803 of this title.

( b ) Opt out ( 1 ) In general A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless ( A ) such financial institution clearly and conspicuously discloses to the consumer, in writing or in electronic form or other form permitted by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, that such information may be disclosed to such third party ; ( B ) the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that such information is initially disclosed, to direct that such information not be disclosed to such third party ; and ( C ) the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option.

Navy federal is in violation of ( B, C ). I was not given opportunity to have my information NOT be disclosed! And was not not given the chance to excerise the nondisclosure option. Also this said account is a charge off which is consider a certificate of indebtness ( income ) WHICH CAN NOT BE ON MY CONSUMER REPORT Please make them aware that i am prepared to take legal action if this violation isnt fixed IMMEDIATELY UPN RECEIPT OF THIS COMPLAINT

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing this letter to report a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by a creditor. I recently checked my credit report and found that the creditor had listed inaccurate information, which has negatively affected my credit score. The creditor did not follow the regulations laid out in the FCRA, which mandates that creditors must report accurate information to the credit bureaus. 

According to the FCRA, if a creditor fails to report the correct information, they have committed a violation that can be reported to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. I hereby request that an investigation be conducted into this matter so that the creditor can be held accountable for their actions. Additionally, I urge the bureau to take necessary action and ensure that the creditor corrects the inaccurate reporting to the credit bureaus. 

I believe the creditor has violated the law and my rights under the FCRA, and I request appropriate legal action to be taken. Thank you for your attention to this matter, and I look forward to receiving your response. 

Credit Report XXXX XXXX Inquires Dates XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Navy Federal Credit Union XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Disputed all inquiries 5 times Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative: A charge off account is showing on my report & the creditor told me that I can not get a copy of the 1099-C document because they did not officially charge off the debt and they didn't take a write off which is a violation because it says on my credit report that it is charged off which equates to false reporting & not reporting 100 % accurately. FCRA violations refers to a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which is a federal law that regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer credit information. Federal law requires that consumer reporting agencies follow reasonable procedures to ensure 100 % accuracy of the information contained in their credit reports. If a consumer suffers damages as a result of a FCRA violation they may be entitled to bring a private lawsuit against the CRA and recover actual damages, statutory damages, and attorney 's fees. These accounts listed on my letter are not 100 % correct and I demand them to be investigated completely.

End of XXXX, I receive a phone call from assistant bank manager. Called back, no response in XXXX. Called back 3x more, still no return call until XX/XX/XXXX stating it's been too long and the credit union no longer can assist me past 60 days. I need assistance to get my money back that the credit union did not protect or follow through with protecting my account.

Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, my XXXX  ( XXXX XXXX, XXXX ) & I applied for a mortgage online on their website. The loan number assigned was # XXXX. We received an automated email & later received an email from XXXX XXXX explaining the process. During our application process, I uploaded letters explaining our situation regarding jobs, child support, etc. XXXX never said anything about what I uploaded. She simply referred our application to underwriting. I don't even think she read any of the attachments or I am sure she would've asked for clarification before sending to UW as a prudent worker would. 

I was then shocked to receive 2 denial package emails on XX/XX/XXXX @ XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX  saying the wrong denial reasons for me. This complaint is only about my part of the application because I can't speak for XXXX 's credit. 

The denial letters indicate the 2  principal reasons for my denial as : 1. Delinquent past or present obligations & 2. Excessive obligations in relation to income. This is why I am complaining. 

# 1 - My credit is excellent. I do NOT have a single delinquency, judgment, or collection on my credit reports. So, they are clearly referring to someone else. That reason does no refer to my credit profile at all. I have almost an XXXX credit score. What delinquency are they thinking they are seeing? I only use 2 % of my credit limit on top of that. So, this is a complete lie! 

# 2 - I do not have excessive obligations in relation to my income. The only debt I have is student loan debt which normally my monthly obligation is {$0.00} per month on the Income Based Repayment Plan but now it is around {$110.00} mo ( they should be using what my loan servicer requires me to pay ; not some made up amount that they come up with based upon the balance of my student loans when I will eventually be using the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  program ), a personal loan with XXXX with a payment of {$1200.00} mo., a XXXX XXXX car loan for XXXX mo, & a small balance on my XXXX credit card. I was never told my options should I pay off my credit card and car. They just denied me using someone else 's credit profile. I thought underwriting would normally give a customer their options before just kicking them to the curb, but I guess not. I could see if my credit was as they indicated, but it is the polar opposite which is why this is so disturbing to me. 

# 3 - On their denial notice, they listed my credit score as XXXX, which was even lower than my XXXX app showed when I applied. They listed that the reason my score was this amount was because of : Too Many Accounts with Balances ( untrue ), Too Many Inquiries Last 12 Months ( untrue ), Too Many Accounts Recently Opened ( untrue - literally only have 1 or 2 new accounts which are the personal and auto loan. The auto loan is almost paid off. ), Ratio of Balance To Limit On Bank Revolving Or Other Rev Accounts Too High ( untrue - My balances are EXTREMELY low on my revolving accounts. I use about 2 % of my available credit. So, I do not understand this! ) I have worked so hard to have excellent credit & to have XXXX XXXX deny me for reasons that don't apply to my credit profile is very disturbing. I pay all of my debt on time, and I shouldn't be penalized for anyone else 's credit issues. 

# 4 - The last issue that I have is when I went through their application process online, it never said that they'd be pulling my credit from multiple credit report agencies. I only applied for a prequalification to see where we stood in attempting to purchase a home together. I just found out that they pulled my credit with XXXX AND XXXX. The 2 denial notices they emailed me on XX/XX/XXXX indicated that they only pulled XXXX. I didn't give them permission to pull from everywhere just for them to still get my credit score wrong & deny me for a reason that doesn't apply to what they are even looking at for me. They need to delete that XXXX inquiry! The documents I reviewed and electronically signed did not say that they would be pulling from multiple companies. They are not transparent & this is unethical. 

This entire process has been a nightmare because they get you to go through the entire process, pull your credit, and THEN require you to pay almost {$45.00} to continue going through the process. Had I known they were going to use someone else 's credit report information after pulling mine twice and still deny me, I would've never paid them. Then to send me 2 emails at XXXX XXXX  & XXXX XXXX  makes me believe that someone was working the overnight shift and was tired which caused them to make that huge mistake on our application. 

When I decide to go through this process again, I will definitely not go through NFCU.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: Dear Navy Federal Credit Union have composed this complaint based on Navy Federal Credit Union furnishing information that is tarnishing my creditworthiness, emphasizing the necessity for both parties to operate in good faith. I have operated in good faith and will continue to do so. I expect Navy Federal Credit Union to demonstrate the same courtesy. Im going to take the time to educate Navy Federal Credit Union on consumer laws since Navy Federal Credit Union is causing me direct harm as well as violating federal laws. According to 15 USC 1681a ( f ), the term consumer reporting agency means any person who, for monetary fees, dues, or on a cooperative nonprofit basis, regularly engages in whole or in part in the practice of assembling or evaluating consumer credit information or other information on consumers for the purpose of furnishing consumer reports to third parties, and who uses any means or facility of interstate commerce for the purpose of preparing or furnishing consumer reports. Did you catch the part about engaging in whole or in part? I sure did. By the federal definition I have kindly provided, Navy Federal Credit Union is a consumer reporting agency furnishing my consumer information to third parties, including XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX, which are also consumer reporting agencies. XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are third parties due to the simple fact that they are separate entities from I the consumer and Navy Federal Credit Union. Furthermore, since Navy Federal Credit Union is federally categorized as a credit reporting agency under 15 USC 1681a ( f ), my written instructions as the consumer must be followed without further delay. The written instructions of the consumer trump all forms of permissible purpose. Let me reiterate, I am invoking my rights under 15 USC 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ). I am giving clear instructions to Navy Federal Credit Union to update its tradeline to paid as agreed never late on my consumer report. Furthermore, now that I have educated Navy Federal Credit Union on its proper legal role as a consumer reporting agency under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( a ), Navy Federal Credit Union has to launch an investigation into my dispute and disclose the results of the investigation no later than 30 days from receipt of this complaint. Failure to launch an investigation and follow my written instruction will be willful non-compliance under 15 U.S.C. 1681n ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), and under this provision, I am entitled to {$1000.00} per violation. Needless to say, Navy Federal Credit Union has racked up quite a few violations. I expect my written instructions to be followed immediately! I am fed up with Navy Federal Credit Unions actions that are directly affecting my reputation and creditworthiness. Let me remind Navy Federal Credit Union that we are communicating through a government agency website. Please keep in mind what I said earlier about operating in good faith. To reiterate my demands regarding the handling of my consumer report, it is imperative that both parties operate in good faith and adhere to the legal obligations outlined in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). As per my rights under 15 USC 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), I am directing Navy Federal Credit Union to promptly update its tradeline to paid as agreed never late on my consumer report. This action is non-negotiable and must be completed within XXXX  days. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( a ), Navy Federal Credit Union is obligated to launch an investigation into my dispute and provide the results within XXXX  days of receipt. Failure to comply with this requirement will result in legal action and civil penalties.

I have my contract from the refinance and can submit it later if needed.

A side note. Two credit card accounts were closed during this distressful and emotional time in her life. The debtor sent a negotiable instrument on XX/XX/XXXX, with no reply. Sent a Notice Opportunity to Cure on XX/XX/XXXX, and Notice of Default in XX/XX/XXXX, a Certificate of Non-Response on XX/XX/XXXX. The debtors account was never credited nor were the negotiable instrument ( s ) returned. NFCU violated the Federal Reserve Act by displaying a pattern of misconduct, engaging in an unsafe or unsound practice in conducting the affairs of a credit union and breaching fiduciary duties. I've paid off over XXXX in debt in the last two years trying to rebuild credit and my credit score has trickled upwards. NFCU falsely reporting my credit limit has negatively affected my credit rebuild for over a year now and it's not right, it's not ethical. Why does their system get to pick and choose and XXXX over consumers. 

Once all of my debt is paid off through this institution I am no longer going to bank with them. When it comes to working with customer about the banks mistakes the take home last place.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Hello! My situation is unique, and your options don't coincide with what's going on. So, I will explain it below. 

I applied for a personal loan on XX/XX/23 on Navy Federal Credit Union 's website. I keep my credit reports frozen, so I lifted the freeze just to apply for this loan. I asked for $ XXXX, but was counteroffered $ XXXX on XX/XX/23 online. 

Before declining their offer, I decided that I wanted to apply for an auto loan instead to pay off my XXXX XXXX XXXX. So, I emailed XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/23 asking if I did this, would they be pulling my credit again because I didn't want them to. They responded with a vague answer that it was up to the discretion of their lending department but they couldn't guarantee that they wouldn't pull it again. At this point, my credit reports were frozen again. 

So, I declined their personal loan offer on XX/XX/23 & went ahead and applied for the auto loan. Again, I emailed them asking them whether or not they'd have to pull my credit when they just did so on XX/XX/23. The response I got today, XX/XX/23, was the same vague one they sent me before. Then, they said I could call customer service and follow the prompts to the lending department after I asked for a lending manager to call me. 

So, I called XXXX at XXXX XXXX & eventually spoke to XXXX once their automated system called me back. They had a lot of customers ahead of me. I explained the situation to XXXX & he said that he didn't understand why customer service didn't just explain that the first report they pulled on XX/XX/23 was for a non-collateral personal loan. The report they tried to pull yesterday from the same credit reporting agency ( XXXX ) was for a collateral loan, and it's just their policy to pull it again. It doesn't make sense, but that's their policy. 

When I emailed them earlier today, I emailed my credit score along with proof that they already pulled my credit 3 days ago. My credit hasn't changed in 3 days & the vague email response just keeps stating that it's up to " their discretion '' whether or not they will use my XX/XX/23 credit report. If it's up to their discretion, then they are saying that they have the ability to use the report that they already have in their possession to make their decision on my auto loan application if they choose to. Them trying to pull it again yesterday would've caused me to lose more points from my score had my report not been frozen, and that's not okay with me. 

When I asked to speak to a manager earlier today, I wasn't given that opportunity. I'd like to apply for this loan with them, but I will go to XXXX, if necessary. This policy is illogical & doesn't seem to protect the customer at all.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Account number : XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX Violation of the law. Pursuant 15 USC 1681a 2 ( A ) ( i ). Delete these accounts or remove the late payments to protect your company from lawsuits.

NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL To Whom It May Concern : I recently received a copy of my XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report, and I noticed you NATIONAL FINANCE CO 230 are reporting my transactions and experiences specifically late payments that you have posted on my consumer report from multiple accounts : Your company is in clear violation of the law. Pursuant 15 USC 1681a 2 ( A ) ( i ) EXCLUSIONS- Except as provided in paragraph ( 3 ), the term consumer report does not include ( A ) subject to section 1681s3 of this title, any ( i ) a report containing information solely as to transactions or experiences between the consumer and the person making the report ; THE LAW CLEARLY STATES : Transactions between the consumer ( ME ) and the person ( YOU ) NATIONAL FINANCE CO 230 Making the report is NOT INCLUDED on my Consumer report! 


Late payment is a transactional history, My HISTORY with your company. CONGRESS clearly states that the reporting of Transactions or experiences between the CONSUMER and the PERSON making the report is not included in the consumer reports!

YOU HAVE VIOLATED THE FCRA 15USC 1681a 2Ai by reporting this transaction or experience on my consumer which CONGRESS clearly states IS NOT included on my CONSUMER REPORTS.

You have 10 calendar days to update my Transaction/Payment history and DELETE all late payments from the accounts listed in this letter and all accounts listed on my credit reports from your company.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: A charge off account is showing on my report & the creditor told me that I can not get a copy of the 1099-C document because they did not officially charge off the debt and they didn't take a write off which is a violation because it says on my credit report that it is charged off which equates to false reporting & not reporting 100 % accurately. FCRA violations refers to a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which is a federal law that regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer credit information. Federal law requires that consumer reporting agencies follow reasonable procedures to ensure 100 % accuracy of the information contained in their credit reports. If a consumer suffers damages as a result of a FCRA violation they may be entitled to bring a private lawsuit against the CRA and recover actual damages, statutory damages, and attorney 's fees. These accounts listed on my letter are not 100 % correct and I demand them to be investigated completely.

I am deeply concerned about the disregard for consumer rights demonstrated by XXXX in handling this matter. The failure to address my grievances promptly and accurately reflects poorly on XXXX 's commitment to fair and transparent practices.

In NAVY FEDERAL CREDIT UNION AND XXXX XXXX terms and conditions they agreed not to share my information with non affiliates. I have a right to privacy and Per the Privacy Act of 1974 as a federally protected consumer I am now revoking any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you written, non written, verbal, and nonverbal per 5 U.S. Code 552a. Per the FCRA as a federally protected consumer I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you written, non written, verbal, and non verbal per 15 USC 6802. I shall also point out their responsibility pursuant 15 U.S. Code section 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) ( ii ) : ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.NAVY FEDERAL CREDIT UNION AND XXXX XXXX must also refund the remaining balance of the consumer account upon its termination. This is your 7 day notice to return ALL money due from this consumer account. XXXX Treatment of credit balances ; account termination. ( a ) Credit balances. When a credit balance in excess of { { { {$1.00} } } } is created on a credit account ( through transmittal of funds to a creditor in excess of the total balance due on an account, through rebates of unearned finance charges or insurance premiums, or through amounts otherwise owed to or held for the benefit of the consumer ), the creditor shall : ( 1 ) Credit the amount of the credit balance to the consumer 's account ; ( 2 ) Refund any part of the remaining credit balance within seven business days from receipt of a written request from the consumer ; ( 3 ) Make a good faith effort to refund to the consumer by cash, check, or money order, or credit to a deposit account of the consumer, any part of the credit balance remaining in the account for more than six months. No further action is required if the consumer 's current location is not known to the creditor and can not be traced through the consumer 's last known address or telephone number. ( b ) Account termination. ( 1 ) A creditor shall not terminate an account prior to its expiration date solely because the consumer does not incur a finance charge. ( 2 ) Nothing in paragraph ( b ) ( 1 ) of this section prohibits a creditor from terminating an account that is inactive for three or more consecutive months. An account is inactive for purposes of this paragraph if no credit has been extended ( such as by purchase, cash advance or balance transfer ) and if the account has no outstanding balance. ( c ) Timely settlement of estate debts ( 1 ) General rule. ( i ) Reasonable policies and procedures required. For credit card accounts under an open-end ( not home-secured ) consumer credit plan, card issuers must adopt reasonable written policies and procedures designed to ensure that an administrator of an estate of a deceased accountholder can determine the amount of and pay any balance on the account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Application to joint accounts. Paragraph ( c ) of this section does not apply to the account of a deceased consumer if a joint accountholder remains on the account. ( 2 ) Timely statement of balance ( i ) Requirement. Upon request by the administrator of an estate, a card issuer must provide the administrator with the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Safe harbor. For purposes of paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) ( i ) of this section, providing the amount of the balance on the account within 30 days of receiving the request is deemed to be timely. ( 3 ) Limitations after receipt of request from administrator ( i ) Limitation on fees and increases in annual percentage rates. After receiving a request from the administrator of an estate for the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account, a card issuer must not impose any fees on the account ( such as a late fee, annual fee, or over-the-limit fee ) or increase any annual percentage rate, except as provided by XXXX ( b ) ( 2 ). ( ii ) Limitation on trailing or residual interest. A card issuer must waive or rebate any additional finance charge due to a periodic interest rate if payment in full of the balance disclosed pursuant to paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) of this section is received within 30 days after disclosure.

'' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX, XXXX and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time.

" I am opting out of your reporting services.

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint against Navy Federal Credit Union concerning an unauthorized transaction and a fraudulent loan application made using my identity, which directly violates the Electronic Funds Transfer Act ( EFTA ) and Regulation E ( 12 CFR Part 1005 ).

The Electronic Funds Transfer Act ( EFTA ), codified at 15 U.S.C. 1693-1693r, was enacted to provide a basic framework establishing the rights, liabilities, and responsibilities of participants in electronic funds transfer systems. The primary goal of the EFTA is to protect consumers engaging in electronic transfers, including ATM withdrawals, direct deposits, and transfers for bill payments.

12 CFR Part 1005, commonly referred to as Regulation E, implements the EFTA and sets forth the rules that financial institutions must follow regarding electronic funds transfers ( EFTs ). It provides guidelines to protect consumers when they use electronic systems to transfer money and outlines the procedures for resolving errors on accounts. 


**Incident Description : ** - On XX/XX/XXXX, a loan application was forged in my name for {$3900.00} ( Reference Number : XXXX ). 
- Simultaneously, an unauthorized transfer of {$4900.00} was made from my account. 
- Navy Federal was notified within XXXX minutes of the incident. Despite providing all requested documentation, including a Declaration of Forgery/Fraud, my claims have been repeatedly denied, with the focus solely on the transfer and not on the fraudulent loan application and the associated events surrounding these transactions. 

**Violations and Concerns** XXXX. **Non-Compliance with EFTA and Regulation E** : Navy Federal failed to adhere to the liability limitations and notification requirements under Regulation E, which mandates specific responsibilities for financial institutions in the case of unauthorized transfers.

2. **Failure to Protect Consumer Rights under EFTA/Regulation E** : Navy Federal has not fulfilled its obligations to limit my liability for unauthorized electronic fund transfers and to conduct a comprehensive investigation.

3. **Inadequate Fraud Handling Procedures** : The process and response to my fraud alerts and claim submissions have been grossly inadequate, highlighting potential systemic issues within Navy Federals fraud management practices. 

XXXX. **Unauthorized Inquiry and Adverse Impact on Consumer Report** : An unauthorized credit inquiry was made on XX/XX/XXXX as part of a fraudulent loan application ( Reference Number : XXXX ) forged in my name. This inquiry has been recorded on my consumer report and has had an adverse and unfair impact on my XXXX XXXX. Unauthorized inquiries can decrease a consumer 's credit score and are detrimental to one 's financial health and ability to secure future credit under fair terms. 

The presence of this inquiry, linked to fraudulent activities not instigated nor authorized by me, directly contravenes the principles of accurate and fair credit reporting as stipulated under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). It is imperative that such inaccuracies are corrected promptly to mitigate any further negative impact on my financial reputation and creditworthiness. 

**Key Provisions and Violations under EFTA and Regulation E** 1. Error Resolution Procedures ( 12 CFR 1005.11 ) : Financial institutions are required to investigate errors reported by consumers regarding electronic funds transfers on their account statements. The institution must complete its investigation within specific time frames and correct any error promptly.

Violation : NFCU Failed to investigate or resolve errors as required which lead to liability for the resulting damages to the me as the consumer.

2. Liability of Consumer for Unauthorized Transfers ( 12 CFR 1005.6 ) : Limits the amount a consumer can be held liable for in cases of lost or stolen access devices, such as debit cards, provided the consumer notifies the institution within specified timeframes.

Violation : NFCU failed to limit my liability as the consumer as stipulated, it may be required to refund the unauthorized amounts and may be subject to additional damages. 

XXXX. Initial Disclosures ( 12 CFR 1005.7 ) : Institutions must provide detailed disclosures before a consumer agrees to participate in an EFT service. Disclosures should include conditions of the service, fees, liability rules, and error resolution processes. 
Violation : NFCUs lack of adequate disclosure calls for adminstrative enforcement actions and the requirement to make restitution to me as the affected consumer. 



**Additional Concerns Over Denial Decision** The denial of my claims by Navy Federal Credit Union not only exacerbates the financial distress caused by the unauthorized transactions but also fundamentally undermines the principles of fairness, equity, and the fiduciary relationship expected between a financial institution and its depositors. As a holder of an account insured by the National Credit Union Administration ( NCUA ), I believed in a guaranteed level of protection and fiduciary care that has been conspicuously absent in this instance.

3. **Breach of Fiduciary Duty** : Navy Federal 's decision to deny the claim disregards the duty of prudence, care, and loyalty owed to me as a depositor. The swift notification of the fraudulent activities was met with inadequate and dismissive responses, failing to uphold the trust placed in them by their members. 

XXXX. **Fiduciary Duty Neglected** : The handling of my fraud claim demonstrates a neglect of these fiduciary duties. The lack of a thorough investigation into the unauthorized transactions the subsequent denial of my claims without substantial justification suggests that Navy Federal has not acted with the required level of care and diligence.

5. **Conflict of Interest** : The handling of my case suggests a potential conflict of interest, where the financial institutions procedures for fraud prevention and claim resolution may unduly favor minimizing their financial exposure over protecting consumers, depositors, and beneficial owners ' interests. Such a conflict is detrimental to the trust and safety expected in banking relations. This raises serious concerns about the internal practices and protocols of Navy Federal, particularly regarding the impartiality and integrity of the fraud management process.

6. **Violation of Equitable Indemnity Principles** : The concept of equitable indemnity, where losses should be shifted based on the relationship between the parties and not merely contractual obligations, should compel Navy Federal to accept responsibility for the losses incurred as a result of unauthorized access and transactions. Their failure to do so defies the principles of equitable treatment, which are critical in financial governance.

7. **Equitable Indemnity and NCUA Insurance** : Furthermore, my account with Access Number XXXX is insured by the NCUA, which is designed to protect against losses like those I have encountered. The failure to apply the principles of equitable indemnity in this situationwhere the loss should shift from me to the institution based on our relationship, not on the intent or fault of the parties involveddefies the purpose of such insurance. The denial of my claim prevents me from benefiting from this protection, effectively denying me the equitable relief I am entitled to under the circumstances.

Given these serious concerns, it is imperative that the CFPB conduct a comprehensive review not only of the specific incidents but also of Navy Federals overall approach to handling such sensitive matters. It is essential that corrective measures are implemented to restore confidence and ensure that statutory as well as ethical obligations towards consumers are rigorously upheld. I urge the CFPB to consider these points seriously and to provide the necessary equitable relief to rectify the financial and emotional harm inflicted upon me through no fault of my own. Your intervention is crucial in not only addressing this individual case but in reinforcing the integrity of the credit union system at large. 

**Liability and Enforcement** Civil Liability ( 15 U.S.C. 1693m ) : Consumers may recover actual damages and in some cases additional statutory damages for violations. The law also provides for the recovery of attorney 's fees and court costs. A class action lawsuit may be filed for statutory damages for each named plaintiff and for the class, subject to a cap.

Administrative Enforcement : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) is primarily responsible for enforcing Regulation E. State Attorney Generals may also enforce the provisions of the EFTA and Regulation E. Violations can lead to both regulatory sanctions and direct enforcement actions, including fines and orders for corrective actions.

Consumer complaint narrative: FCRA 15 USC 6802 ( a ) Notice requirements Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, a financial institution may not, directly or through any affiliate, disclose to a nonaffiliated third party any nonpublic personal information, unless such financial institution provides or has provided to the consumer a notice that complies with section 6803 of this title. ( b ) Opt out ( 1 ) In general A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless- ( A ) such financial institution clearly and conspicuously discloses to the consumer, in writing or in electronic form or other form permitted by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, that such information may be disclosed to such third party ; ( B ) the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that such information is initially disclosed, to direct that such information not be disclosed to such third party ; and ( C ) the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Unauthorized Credit Reporting and Demand for Resolution Reference to Federal and XXXX XXXX, North Carolina Laws Dear NAVY FCU, I am writing to address a blatant violation regarding the unauthorized reporting of information to my credit report, as confirmed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under Sections 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), 1681c ( a ) ( 2 ), and 1681s-2 ( a ), and identity fraud laws specific to XXXX XXXX XXXX North Carolina XXXX 

It has unequivocally come to my attention that NAVY FCU has engaged in unauthorized reporting to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent. Federal law, as outlined in the FCRA, explicitly mandates that the consent of the consumer is a non-negotiable requirement for such reporting activities under Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ).

In addition to federal law, North Carolina state law, specifically N.C.G.S. 75-61 and 75-62, emphasizes the necessity of consumer consent for credit reporting. Furthermore, North Carolina Identity Theft Protection Act establishes clear guidelines for the fair reporting and protection of consumer credit information. Identity fraud laws in North Carolina underscore the severity of unauthorized access and misuse of personal information. 

I assert with unwavering certainty that I have not provided consent for NAVY FCU to report any information to my credit report. This undeniable lack of explicit permission constitutes a blatant violation of my rights, resulting in potential damage to my creditworthiness and an unequivocal disregard for federal and state laws. 

I demand, with the utmost certainty, that NAVY FCU immediately ceases any further reporting of information to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent, as mandated by Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA and applicable North Carolina statutes. Failure to comply within the stipulated 30-day timeframe will be viewed as willful noncompliance, subject to penalties under applicable laws, including identity fraud laws. 

I emphasize that obtaining consent is not a discretionary choice but a legal obligation under these specific sections of the FCRA and North Carolina state law. This is not a negotiation ; it is a demand for compliance with both federal and state regulations, protecting consumers like myself from unauthorized and damaging credit reporting. 

I anticipate your immediate attention to this matter and expect that NAVY FCU will promptly rectify these egregious violations, respecting my rights under federal and state laws. 

Done in good faith.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 USC 1681 Section 602 ( a ) states, " Consumer reporting agencies must exercise their responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and respect for the consumers privacy. '' XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are such agencies, and as a consumer, I am entitled to ensure my private information is not shared. This right is supported by 15 USC 6801, which asserts, " Congress 's policy is that financial institutions have a continuing obligation to respect customer privacy and protect the security and confidentiality of nonpublic personal information. '' XXXX XXXX qualifies as a financial institution under this section.

According to 15 USC 1681 Section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ), " A consumer reporting agency may provide a consumer report only in accordance with the consumers written instructions. '' XXXX XXXX the financial institution and XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX do not have my consent, whether verbal, non-verbal, written, implied, or otherwise, to furnish my information. Any and all forms of consent previously granted to these agencies are revoked.

Additionally, 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) requires that " A financial institution must not disclose nonpublic personal information to nonaffiliated third parties unless the consumer is informed about how to exercise their nondisclosure option. '' XXXX XXXX, have not provided me with this information. Furthermore, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) stipulates that " No consumer reporting agency may include adverse items of information, other than criminal convictions, that are more than seven years old. '' The reporting of this adverse item without my permission is unlawful.

15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) mandates that " No person shall furnish information to a consumer reporting agency if they know or have reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. '' 15 U.S. Code 1681e requires consumer reporting agencies to " maintain reasonable procedures to avoid violations of section 1681c and limit reports to the purposes specified in section 1681b. '' XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are not adhering to these reasonable procedures. Lastly, 12 CFR 1016.7 allows consumers to " opt out at any time. '' Therefore, I am opting out of your reporting services.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint against Caine and Weiner, a debt collection agency, for their continued and unlawful attempts to collect a debt that I do not owe. Despite never having conducted any business with this company, they have persisted in their collection efforts, causing significant distress and harm to my reputation. 

Summary of the Issue : Debt Validation Request Ignored : On XX/XX/year>, I sent a debt validation letter to Caine and Weiner, requesting specific information regarding the alleged debt. They failed to provide the requested documentation, violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) 1006.30a ( a ) - No Parking Rule. 

Cease and Desist Ignored : I also sent a cease and desist letter and a volunti nonfit injra letter, demanding that Caine and Weiner cease all communications and collection efforts regarding this alleged debt. They have ignored my requests, continuing to pursue the debt. 

Violation of XXXXederal Laws : Caine and Weiner 's actions are in direct violation of several federal laws, including : FDCPA 1006.30a ( a ) : They have continued collection activities without validating the debt.

18 USC 1028a : Their actions amount to aggravated identity theft by attempting to collect a debt not owed.

15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : They are prohibited from furnishing information they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate.

Impact : The inaccurate reporting of this debt has severely damaged my character, reputation, and general mode of living. It has adversely affected my ability to obtain credit for personal and housing purposes, causing significant financial and emotional distress.

Legal Violations : 15 USC 1681s-2 : Duty of furnishers to provide accurate information. They have reported inaccurate information despite being notified of the errors.

15 USC 1681n and 15 USC 1681o : Willful and negligent noncompliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. 
15 USC 1692k : Violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Demands : I demand that Caine and Weiner immediately : Cease all communications and attempts to collect this alleged debt.

Delete the erroneous account from all consumer reporting agencies.

Provide a free copy of my credit report after the changes have been made.

Failure to comply with these demands within 10 calendar days will result in legal action for consumer law violations. I will seek {$1000.00} per violation for : Defamation of Character ( per se ) Negligent Enablement of Identity Fraud FDCPA 15 USC 1692g violations FCRA 15 USC 1681 violations for willful noncompliance - 616 [ 15 U.S.C. 1681n ] Account Information : Account Name : XXXX XXXX I urge the CFPB to investigate this matter thoroughly and take appropriate action against Caine and Weiner to prevent further violations and protect consumers from their unlawful practices. 

Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
